Which raises a grating question: How long will the revulsion last—not only in Germany but in the U.S., Canada, Japan, Australia, even eternally neutral Switzerland, which has joined in?
Even as Russian divisions encircled Ukraine, Chancellor Olaf Scholz went off on a mission to Moscow, competing for the broker’s fee with French President Emmanuel Macron.
Suddenly, all Bundestag factions save the pro-Russian Left Party, descendant of the East German Communists, project a mood change that defies past pliancy.
Pressed too hard, Mr. Putin will demonstrably move into Xi Jinping’s embrace to damage the U.S. Never mind that China and Russia are natural rivals.
Suddenly, the country at the fulcrum of the European balance has stopped seesawing, plunked down in the West, and traded striped pants for fatigues.
Mr. Joffe, a fellow at Stanford’s Hoover Institution, teaches international politics at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies.
Will Germans really shiver for Kyiv next winter, or face down Mr. Putin, who has raised the angst level by placing his nuclear forces on alert?
A perfect welfare state like Germany is unlikely to max out defense spending overnight, especially while Covid is claiming billions of euros.
Blame geography and Otto von Bismarck, who famously counseled: “Never cut the link to St. Petersburg.” Russia is so near, and America so far.
Since 1970 the Federal Republic has financed a vast network that would feed the country’s industrial machine with plentiful Russian gas.
For more than 50 years, Bonn and later Berlin had taken a pacific approach: Don’t rile the Russians; enmesh them in trade and diplomacy.
Resentment reaches all the way to the soccer pitch where Schalke, a prominent club, has torn the Gazprom logo from its blue jerseys.

Mr. Scholz, this peace-minded Social Democrat, unleashed a diplomatic revolution, turning Ostpolitik upside down.
